choices.C: ALTER TABLE t1 WITH ENCRYPTION USING MASTER KEY;

questions.question_text: What is the correct syntax for using transparent data encryption with an existing InnoDB table?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Run a tablespace encryption operation. In this example, a general tablespace named ts1 is encrypted.
mysql> ALTER TABLESPACE ts1 ENCRYPTION = 'Y';

https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-data-encryption.html

Selected Answer: A
f the --only-known-file-types option is specified, mysqlbackup only backs up those types of files that are data files for MySQL or its built-in storage engines, which, besides the ibdata* files, have the following extensions:

.ARM: ARCHIVE table metadata

.ARZ: ARCHIVE table data

.CSM: CSV table metadata

.CSV: CSV table data

.ibd: InnoDB tablespace created using the file-per-table mode

.MRG: Merge storage engine references to other tables

.MYD: MyISAM data

.MYI: MyISAM indexes

choices.C: The backup includes only data files and their metadata.
choices.D: Only InnoDB data and log files are backed up.
choices.A: Only files for MySQL or Its built-in storage engines are backed
choices.B: Only non-encrypted files are backed up.
choices.E: Only tables stored in their own tablespaces are backed up.

choices.A: MySQL server was not started due to a problem while executing process 2732.
choices.C: systemd found the mysqld service disabled and failed to start it.
choices.D: systemd waited for 30 seconds before timing out and start up failed.
choices.E: systemd attempted to start mysqld, found another systemd mysqld process running, and shut it down.
choices.B: MySQL server continued to start up even though another process existed.

questions.question_text:
You have just installed MySQL on Oracle Linux and adjusted your /etc/my.cnf parameters to suit your installation.
Examine the output:
//IMG//

What statement is true about the start attempt?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It should be A

Correct answer should be D
Service has been correctly enabled. No indication that systemd found another systemd mysql proces and shut it down.

choices.C: The instances use different socket names.
choices.D: The instances have appropriate net masks set.
choices.B: The instances listen on different IP addresses.
choices.A: The instances use different user accounts unique to each instance.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I choose B because more logic.
socket doesn't mention any port.
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql-shell/8.0/en/mysql-shell-connection-socket.html

Selected Answer: C
Each MySQL instance should use a different socket file to avoid conflicts. You can specify the socket file for each MySQL instance in their respective configuration files (typically my.cnf or my.ini).
B. If each mysql instance has a unique port, they can all listen on that port.

comments.content:
I mean if they all have a unique ip address, they can use the same port. So B. 
Not C, sockets have nothing to do with ports.

questions.question_text: How can mysql_multi be configured to allow MySQL instances to use the same port number?
What does the slave I/O thread do?

choices.B: monitors and schedules I/O calls to the subsystem for the relay logs
choices.D: reads the relay log and executes the events contained in them
choices.A: connects to the master and requests it to send updates recorded in its binary logs
choices.C: acquires a lock on the binary log for reading each event to be sent to the slave
